Dear Franks
Thanks for your prompt and informative letter, and Ifll reply
in kind. Perhaps these things will be discussed after I arrive in
New Jfork, but in any case;
1, I see no real problem in cooperating with the Acceptance
people, or am I being naive? Surely if they turn down a program
that we suggest, plan, and have produced, they must explain in
detail the reasons. Then I should inagine the thing could be
polished up or argued out to a successful decision. I realize
this matter has a history of which I am only slightly aware, but
I feel it could be worked out.
2. I think you're completely ri^it here—that new program
ideas are badly needed. Are we really contributing anything to
American radio that is any different, or are we simply providing
finer content in the same old wrappings? This has worried me for
seven years since I came into the non-ccmmercial field. Some pro¬
grams have been different in form and production as well as in
content, but most have been conventional. I'm afraid this short¬
coming, if it is aich, will require good brains applied over a long
period—perhaps we can supply such thinking in a separate meeting?
At any rate, I think the ifbollowing ideas might be worth considering*
/
Balladry in America — series of genuine folksongs, perhaps
with two or three programs produced by member stations in unique
areas, but preferably with a production team to give unity to the
entire series. Not regional pseudo-balladry, but the real article
over a national area.
^ Atomic Energy — man and his search fo r a way of bettering his
lot, finally his discovery of the secret of atomic energy. What
this discovery means in terms cf destruction, medicine, agriculture,
science, business, an d in terms of man's future civilisation. I
realise this subject matter has been given a good working over, but
I haven't heard a really good series yet.
